Speed comes last and naturally. Practice these cuts whenever you help prepare meals at home — every time you chop, dice, or mince, you are building a skill that will serve you for life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student demonstrate the claw grip safely, perform basic cuts (chop, dice, mince), and explain three food safety principles?

parent_notes: Knife skills require adult supervision for safety. Use a knife appropriate for your child's hand size — large knives are unwieldy and dangerous for small hands. Start with soft vegetables (cucumbers, celery) before progressing to harder ones (carrots, potatoes). The claw grip is the most important safety technique — verify it before allowing any cutting. Do not rush speed; safety and control come first. Many children are nervous about knives, which is healthy — it means they will be careful. Build confidence gradually. These skills are genuinely useful; a child who can safely prepare vegetables can contribute meaningfully to family meal preparation.

title: Research in Action — Gathering Information and Taking Notes
description: Students spend a focused session gathering information for their research project. They practice applying Cornell notes and source evaluation skills to real sources, recording information systematically and creating bibliography entries for each source.
instructions:
1. Review the research plan created in the previous lesson.
2. Set up a research station with available sources.
3. Review note-taking rules: paraphrase, cite the source, use your own words.
4. Student conducts focused research, taking notes from at least 2 sources.
5. Create bibliography entries for all sources used.
6. Check progress against the research plan timeline.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a focused research environment with available sources. Minimize distractions. Have the student's research plan and questions visible for reference.

slides.text: Today is a working session — your job is to find answers to your research questions. Good research is systematic: look for information source by source, take careful notes, and always record where you found each piece of information. The goal is not to read everything but to find the specific information your questions require.

For each source: (1) Evaluate it using CRAAP criteria — is it reliable? (2) Create a bibliography card with all source information. (3) Take Cornell notes, organizing information by research question. (4) Paraphrase — put information in YOUR words. Only copy direct quotes if the exact wording matters, and always use quotation marks. (5) Write the source number on your notes so you know where each fact came from.

Strategies for efficient research: Skim before you read — scan headings, bold words, and topic sentences to find relevant sections quickly. You do not need to read an entire book for one research question. Use the table of contents and index in books. For websites, use the search function. Focus on answering your specific research questions rather than reading everything about the topic.

As you research, new questions may arise. That is normal and good — it means you are thinking deeply about your topic. Add new questions to your list. You may also discover that one of your original questions cannot be answered from available sources. That is also normal — adjust your plan accordingly. Research is a flexible process.

slides.prompt: Conduct focused research for your project: (1) Choose your first source. Evaluate it (CRAAP), create a bibliography card, and take Cornell notes on information relevant to your research questions. (2) Move to a second source and repeat. (3) After researching from both sources, review your notes. Have you found answers to at least 2 of your research questions? What gaps remain? (4) Organize your notes by research question (not by source). This will make writing your report much easier. (5) Update your research plan: What have you accomplished? What still needs to be done?

slides.text: Good research takes time and patience. You are building the foundation of your report one note at a time. Every fact you record, every source you evaluate, and every question you answer is a brick in the structure of your final paper. Continue researching during the week — the more thorough your notes, the easier the writing will be.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student conduct focused research using multiple sources, take organized notes that distinguish between paraphrasing and direct quotes, and create proper bibliography entries?

parent_notes: This is a working session rather than a teaching session — your child is applying previously learned skills independently. Resist the urge to do the research for them, even if it would be faster. The struggle of finding information, evaluating it, and recording it in their own words is where the learning happens. Help with logistics (finding books, accessing websites) but not with content. Check that notes are paraphrased, not copied. If your child finishes early, encourage them to find an additional source or develop their notes further.

title: Subtracting Fractions with Unlike Denominators
description: Students apply the common denominator method to fraction subtraction, including problems requiring borrowing from whole numbers in mixed number subtraction. They practice the complete process from finding LCD through simplifying the answer.
instructions:
1. Review fraction addition with unlike denominators.
2. Show that subtraction follows the same LCD process.
3. Practice basic fraction subtraction problems.
4. Tackle mixed number subtraction without borrowing.
5. Introduce mixed number subtraction with borrowing.
6. Solve real-world subtraction problems.

slides.setup_instructions: Have fraction bars available for demonstration of borrowing. Display the addition steps from yesterday as reference — subtraction follows the same process.

slides.text: Great news: subtracting fractions uses the exact same first steps as adding them. Find the LCD, convert to equivalent fractions, then subtract the numerators (instead of adding). The denominator stays the same. Example: 5/6 - 1/4. LCD of 6 and 4 is 12. Convert: 5/6 = 10/12 and 1/4 = 3/12. Subtract: 10/12 - 3/12 = 7/12.

Mixed number subtraction without borrowing is straightforward: subtract whole numbers and fractions separately. 5 and 3/4 - 2 and 1/3. Whole numbers: 5 - 2 = 3. Fractions: 3/4 - 1/3 = 9/12 - 4/12 = 5/12. Answer: 3 and 5/12.

Mixed number subtraction WITH BORROWING happens when the fraction being subtracted is larger than the fraction you are subtracting from. 4 and 1/6 - 1 and 2/3. Convert fractions: LCD is 6. 1/6 stays as 1/6. 2/3 = 4/6. Problem: 1/6 - 4/6 is not possible. Solution: BORROW 1 from the 4, rename it as 6/6, and add to 1/6: 3 and 7/6 - 1 and 4/6 = 2 and 3/6 = 2 and 1/2.

The borrowing concept is just regrouping — the same idea as borrowing in whole number subtraction. When you borrow 1 from the whole number, you rename it as a fraction with the current denominator: 1 = 6/6 = 8/8 = 12/12. This makes the fraction part large enough to subtract. Always simplify your final answer and check with estimation.

slides.prompt: In your math journal (show all work): (A) 7/8 - 3/5 (B) 5/6 - 2/9 (C) 3 and 2/3 - 1 and 1/4 (D) 6 and 1/8 - 2 and 3/4 (borrowing needed!) (E) 5 and 1/6 - 3 and 5/6 (borrowing needed!) (F) 8 - 2 and 3/7 (borrowing from a whole number). Then solve: A board is 6 and 3/4 feet long. You cut off 2 and 7/8 feet. How long is the remaining board?

slides.text: Fraction subtraction with borrowing is one of the trickiest procedures in elementary math. The key is recognizing WHEN to borrow (when the fraction being subtracted is larger) and HOW to borrow (take 1 from the whole number and convert it to a fraction with the right denominator). Practice until this feels natural — it will come up frequently.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student subtract fractions with unlike denominators, including mixed number subtraction that requires borrowing from the whole number?

parent_notes: Mixed number subtraction with borrowing is often the hardest fraction skill for students. If your child struggles, practice the borrowing step separately: 5 and 1/4 = 4 and 5/4 (borrowed 1 and renamed as 4/4, then added to 1/4). Once they can do this conversion fluently, the full subtraction problem becomes manageable. Use fraction bars to make borrowing visible: show that 5 and 1/4 really is the same amount as 4 and 5/4 by physically moving pieces. Word problems keep the math grounded in reality — the board-cutting problem is something a carpenter actually does.

title: Egyptian Writing and Knowledge — Hieroglyphs, Papyrus, and Medicine
description: Students explore Egyptian achievements in writing, record-keeping, and medicine. They compare hieroglyphic writing to cuneiform, learn about papyrus as a writing material, and discover the surprisingly advanced state of Egyptian medical knowledge.
instructions:
1. Review hieroglyphs from the art lesson.
2. Compare cuneiform and hieroglyphic writing systems.
3. Explain the creation and importance of papyrus.
4. Discuss the Rosetta Stone and how hieroglyphs were decoded.
5. Explore Egyptian medicine: surgery, dentistry, pharmacology.
6. Discuss how Egyptian knowledge was preserved and transmitted.

slides.setup_instructions: Display images of the Rosetta Stone, Egyptian papyrus scrolls, and medical instruments. Have the hieroglyph chart from the art lesson available.

slides.text: The Egyptians developed hieroglyphics independently from Mesopotamian cuneiform. While cuneiform used wedge shapes pressed into clay, hieroglyphics used pictures carved in stone or painted on papyrus. Hieroglyphics could represent sounds (like our alphabet), whole words, or concepts (like 'life' or 'eternity'). The system included over 700 symbols — learning to write was a major achievement.

PAPYRUS was the ancient world's paper. Made from the papyrus reed that grew along the Nile, it was created by slicing the reed's inner pith into thin strips, layering them crosswise, and pressing them together. The natural sap glued the strips into a smooth writing surface. Papyrus scrolls could be stored for thousands of years in Egypt's dry climate — and many have survived.

For over 1,400 years, no one could read hieroglyphics — the knowledge had been lost. Then in 1799, French soldiers in Egypt found the ROSETTA STONE: the same text written in three scripts: hieroglyphics, Demotic (everyday Egyptian), and Greek. Since scholars could read Greek, they used it as a key to decode the other scripts. Jean-Francois Champollion finally cracked the code in 1822, opening 3,000 years of Egyptian history to the world.

Egyptian doctors were remarkably advanced. The Edwin Smith Papyrus (about 1600 BCE) describes 48 surgical cases with detailed observations and treatments — it reads like a modern medical textbook. Egyptian doctors set broken bones, performed surgery, and understood that the pulse was connected to the heart. They used honey as an antibiotic (it actually works), willow bark for pain (the active ingredient is related to aspirin), and created over 700 medicinal recipes.

slides.prompt: In your history journal: (1) Create a comparison chart: Egyptian hieroglyphs vs. Mesopotamian cuneiform. Compare: what they look like, what they were written on, who could read them, what they were used for. (2) The Rosetta Stone is one of the most important archaeological discoveries ever. Write a paragraph explaining why, using the concept of 'key' or 'decoder.' (3) Choose one Egyptian medical achievement that surprises you. Write 3-4 sentences explaining what it was and why it was remarkable for its time. (4) Egyptian honey prescriptions actually worked — scientists now know honey has antibacterial properties. What does this tell us about ancient knowledge?

slides.text: The Egyptians were not just monument builders — they were scientists, doctors, writers, and scholars. Their knowledge of medicine, mathematics, and engineering was not surpassed for thousands of years. The Rosetta Stone reminds us that knowledge can be lost and recovered — and that every writing system is a key to unlocking the thoughts of the past.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student compare Egyptian and Mesopotamian writing systems, explain the significance of the Rosetta Stone, and describe Egyptian achievements in medicine?

parent_notes: The Rosetta Stone story is one of the most exciting in the history of knowledge — the idea that an entire civilization's writings were unreadable for over a millennium and then decoded by a brilliant young linguist captivates children. If possible, show your child an image of the actual Rosetta Stone (it is in the British Museum). The medical knowledge discussion connects to science — Egyptian honey treatments have been validated by modern research, which raises fascinating questions about how ancient peoples discovered effective treatments without understanding the science behind them. This is a good opportunity to discuss the difference between 'it works' and 'we know why it works.'

title: The Three Rock Types — How Rocks Form
description: Students explore how each of the three rock types forms: igneous (from cooled magma/lava), sedimentary (from compressed layers), and metamorphic (from heat and pressure). They examine samples of each type and begin building an understanding of the rock cycle.
instructions:
1. Review rocks as combinations of minerals.
2. Igneous rocks: intrusive (cooled slowly underground) vs. extrusive (cooled quickly on surface).
3. Sedimentary rocks: layers of sediment compressed over time.
4. Metamorphic rocks: existing rocks changed by heat and pressure.
5. Examine and classify rock samples by type.
6. Preview the rock cycle.
materials_needed: Rock samples of each type (granite, basalt, sandstone, limestone, marble, slate)

slides.setup_instructions: Organize rock samples by type if possible, or number them for identification. Display formation diagrams for each rock type. Have magnifying glasses available for close observation.

slides.text: All rocks on Earth belong to one of three families, classified by how they formed. The same minerals can end up in different rock types depending on the process. Understanding rock formation helps us read the geological history of any landscape — every rock tells a story about the conditions under which it was made.

IGNEOUS ROCKS form when molten rock (magma underground, lava on the surface) cools and solidifies. Intrusive igneous rocks (like granite) cool slowly deep underground, forming large visible crystals — you can see the individual mineral grains. Extrusive igneous rocks (like basalt) cool quickly on the surface, forming tiny crystals or even glassy textures because the minerals did not have time to grow large.

SEDIMENTARY ROCKS form in layers. Wind, water, and ice break existing rocks into small pieces (sediment). The sediment is transported by rivers and wind and deposited in layers. Over millions of years, the weight of upper layers compresses lower layers, and minerals cement the grains together. This process is called lithification. Sandstone (from sand), limestone (from marine shells), and shale (from clay) are common sedimentary rocks. Fossils are found almost exclusively in sedimentary rocks.

METAMORPHIC ROCKS form when existing rocks are changed by intense heat and/or pressure — without melting. The minerals recrystallize into new arrangements. Limestone becomes marble. Shale becomes slate. Sandstone becomes quartzite. Granite can become gneiss. The prefix 'meta' means change, and 'morph' means form — metamorphic literally means 'changed form.' (Connect to your Greek roots vocabulary!)

slides.prompt: In your science journal: (1) Create a three-column chart comparing igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic rocks. For each type, describe: how it forms, examples, distinguishing features, and where you would find it. (2) Examine the rock samples. Classify each one as igneous, sedimentary, or metamorphic based on its features. Explain your reasoning. (3) Draw a diagram showing how each rock type forms, with arrows showing the process. (4) The word 'metamorphic' uses the Greek root 'morph' (form/shape). What other words use this root? List at least 3.

slides.text: Every rock you see has a story: it was either born from fire (igneous), built from layers (sedimentary), or transformed by force (metamorphic). Next week we will connect these three types through the rock cycle — the continuous process by which rocks transform from one type to another over millions of years.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe how each of the three rock types forms, classify rock samples by type, and give examples of each?

parent_notes: The three rock types are fundamental earth science knowledge. The key to remember: igneous = fire (think 'ignite'), sedimentary = sediment (layers), metamorphic = changed form. If possible, take your child on a rock hunt in your area — can you find examples of each type? Granite countertops, marble floors, sandstone buildings, and slate roofing tiles are all around us. The Greek root connection (morph = form) ties to the language arts curriculum beautifully. The rock cycle preview sets up next week's lesson.

title: Elements of Art — Texture Real and Implied
description: Students explore the element of texture — both actual (tactile) texture you can feel and implied (visual) texture that creates the illusion of texture on a flat surface. They create a texture collection and practice depicting various textures in their drawings.
instructions:
1. Review line, shape, color, and value.
2. Define actual texture vs. implied texture.
3. Create a texture rubbing collection from real surfaces.
4. Demonstrate techniques for drawing implied textures: fur, wood, stone, water, fabric.
5. Create a drawing that includes at least 5 different implied textures.
6. Discuss how artists use texture to create mood and interest.
materials_needed: Various textured surfaces (bark, coins, fabric, sandpaper, leaves)

slides.setup_instructions: Collect a variety of textured surfaces: tree bark, coins, woven fabric, sandpaper, leaves, corrugated cardboard, embossed wallpaper. Set up a texture exploration station.

slides.text: Texture is the surface quality of an object — how it feels or how it looks like it would feel. We have explored line, shape, color, and value. Texture adds another dimension to art: the sense of touch. Even though you cannot reach into a painting and feel the rough bark of a tree, a skilled artist can make you believe you could.

ACTUAL TEXTURE (also called tactile texture) is texture you can physically feel. A sculpture has actual texture. A collage with fabric, sand, or dried flowers has actual texture. You can close your eyes and experience it. IMPLIED TEXTURE (also called visual texture) creates the illusion of texture on a flat surface through artistic technique. When an artist draws fur, wood grain, or water, you 'feel' the texture with your eyes.

Texture rubbing (frottage) captures actual texture on paper. Place thin paper over a textured surface and rub the side of a crayon across it. The texture appears on the paper. This technique was used by modern artist Max Ernst to create entire artworks. Try it with bark, coins, fabric, and leaves — each creates a completely different pattern.

Drawing implied texture requires different techniques for different surfaces: For WOOD GRAIN — long, wavy parallel lines with knots. For FUR — short, overlapping curved lines in the direction the fur grows. For STONE — irregular shapes with value variation. For WATER — curved, flowing lines with reflections. For FABRIC — soft folds with smooth shading. For METAL — high contrast between highlights and shadows, smooth blending.

slides.prompt: Part 1: Create a texture rubbing collection. Make at least 6 different rubbings from surfaces around you. Mount them in your notebook and label each one. Part 2: Practice drawing implied textures. Create a grid with 6 squares. In each square, draw a different implied texture: wood grain, fur, stone/brick, water, woven fabric, and metal. Use the techniques described and your pencil work from the value lesson. Part 3: Draw a scene that includes at least 4 different textures — for example, a stone cottage with a wooden door, grass in front, and clouds in the sky.

slides.text: Texture adds richness and believability to art. A drawing with varied textures is infinitely more interesting than one with smooth, uniform surfaces. We have now covered five of the seven elements of art: line, shape, color, value, and texture. Next we will explore form and space — the elements that create the illusion of three dimensions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish between actual and implied texture, create texture rubbings, and draw at least 4 different implied textures convincingly?

parent_notes: Texture exploration is naturally engaging — children enjoy the physical process of making rubbings and the challenge of drawing convincing textures. The rubbing collection is a wonderful reference to keep. For the implied texture practice, the key is observation: before drawing wood grain, look carefully at real wood. Before drawing fur, look at a pet or photo. The difference between a beginning artist and a skilled one is often simply how carefully they observe. Encourage your child to look closely at textures all around them — building materials, clothing, food, nature. The five elements of art covered so far provide a complete vocabulary for discussing any visual artwork.
